title.narrative: Feasibility Study for the Climate Adaptation Water and Energy Infrastructure Programme (CAWEP) – Zimbabwe

description.narrative: Detailed feasibility study for FCDO Zimbabwe in order to inform investments in multiple use water and renewable energy infrastructure to enhance climate change adaptation. Increased climate risks and vulnerability in Zimbabwe require significant investments in water and renewable energy in order to enhance climate adaptation in critical sectors such as education, agriculture, health and infectious disease control. The feasibility study will provide a better understanding of the problems, identify opportunities for investment, identify best value for money, strengthen collaboration among development partners together, identify the best delivery channels and set out the scope of works. The feasibility study is also an opportunity to influence the setting up of new climate change, water and renewable energy national priorities and policies and shifting towards increasing climate risk analysis in planning and developing water and renewable energy infrastructure.

Determine the extent to which climate change has affected access to water and energy for education, health and agriculture sectors in Zimbabwe. Identify and design appropriate water and renewable energy infrastructure that helps in reducing the impact of climate risks and building community and institutional adaptation to climate shocks. Identify how best to finance the operations and maintenance (O&M) for this new and existing infrastructure. Identify opportunities for strengthening collaboration/partnerships between development agencies and with investors on climate resilient water and renewable energy infrastructure development. Identify opportunities to strengthen policy, strategies, regulatory and financing mechanisms in education, health and agriculture sectors in order to strengthen response to climate change. Assess the Government of Zimbabwe's capacity to anticipate, prepare and respond to climate shocks.
